summary: Reduce colour palette to one accent colour; remove visual noise
problem_statement: The current UI uses multiple accent colours, borders, and tonal variations that compete for attention and add visual noise. Every distinct colour is a micro-decision the writer's eye must process. A single, intentional accent colour creates a quieter visual field where the only 'loud' element is the writer's own text. Reducing the palette is a prerequisite for the breathing-space and caret work that follows—without tonal calm, whitespace and animation refinements have diminished impact.
in_scope: Audit existing colour usage across the Write view for accent and highlight colours
Consolidate to a single primary accent colour for interactive elements
Remove or neutralise secondary accent colours, decorative borders, and tonal noise
Ensure sufficient contrast ratios (WCAG AA) with the single accent
Update CSS custom properties / design tokens to reflect the reduced palette
requirements: Write view uses at most one accent colour for interactive and highlight elements
Neutral palette (greys, background) remains available for structure but carries no semantic weight
All interactive elements using accent meet WCAG AA contrast (≥4.5:1 text, ≥3:1 non-text)
No regression in readability or discoverability of controls
acceptance_criteria: Only one accent colour is used across the Write view
No secondary accent colours remain in the default Write view
Contrast ratios for accent-coloured elements pass WCAG AA
Design tokens / CSS custom properties are consolidated to a single accent variable
Visual regression: Write view feels calmer without losing affordance clarity
dependencies: P1-uix-01 (Full-width editor layout) — accent applies within the expanded viewport
P1-uix-02 (Slide-out metadata panel) — panel controls adopt the single accent
P1-uix-03 (Non-blocking typography) — formatting affordances use the accent
risks: A single accent may not provide enough differentiation for distinct interactive states (hover, active, focus)
Consolidating colours could inadvertently reduce accessibility if contrast is not re-verified
Designers or stakeholders may push back on perceived 'blandness'
implementation_notes: P2-uix-04 opens Phase 2 (Sensory). All Phase 1 structural work must be complete. Derive hover/active/focus states from the single accent via opacity or lightness shifts rather than introducing new hues. Prefer CSS custom properties (e.g. --accent, --accent-hover, --accent-muted) so downstream atomics (breathing space, caret) inherit the palette automatically. Reference epic DoD: platform feels still, not busy.
